div.l: Aleyn answerde / Iohn wilt thow swa
Than wol I be binethe / bi my crowne
And se how the mele / falles a downe
In to the trouth / that shal be my disport
For in faith / I may ben oon of your sort
I am as ille / a millere as ye
This millere smiled / at here nycete
And thouht / al this is do but for a wile
They wene that no man̄ / may hem bigile
But bi my thrift / yit shal I blere her eye
For al the sleyhte / in her philosophie
The more quēntqutquēnt knakkes / that they make
The more wol I stele / whan that I take
In stede of flour / yit wol I yeve hem bren
The grettest clerkis / be nat wisest men
As whilom to the wolf / thus spak the mare
Of al here art / ne coıı̄unte I nat a tare
Out of the dore / he goth ful pryvily
Whan that he sawh / his tyme softely
He looketh vp and doıı̄un / til he hath foıı̄unde
The clerkes hors / ther as it stood I boıı̄unde
Be hynde the mille / vndir the levesell
And to the hors he goth / fayre and wel
He stripith of the brydel / ryht anoon
And whan the hors was loososlosloos / he bignneth to goon
Toward the fen / ther wilde maris renne
And forth with wehe / thoruh thikke ⁊and thenne
The millere goth a gayn / no worde he sayde
But doth his note / and with the clerkis pleyde
Til here corn / was wel and fayre I grounde
And whan / the mele is sakked / and wel I boıı̄unde
This Iohn goth out / and fond his hors away
And gan to crye / harrawe / and welaway
Our hors is lost Aleyn / for cokkis bonys
Step on thi feet / com of man attonys
Allas our wardeyn has his palfrey lorn
This Aleyn al forget / both mele and corn
And was out of mynde / his housbondrye
